{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","title":"How to Store an Exercise Ball","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>An <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Buy-an-Exercise-Ball\" title=\"Buy an Exercise Ball\">exercise ball</a> is a great tool to work out at home with. However, these are big and bulky, and they never stay where they’re supposed to when you’re not using them. But don’t worry—your exercise ball doesn’t have to roll all over the place when you aren’t using it! There are lots of DIY and store-bought storage solutions you can use to keep your exercise space clean and tidy. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Store-an-Exercise-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Store-an-Exercise-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: DIY Solutions\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"DIY-Solutions\">DIY Solutions</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Hide the ball in a closet if you have space. This might seem too simple, but it’s a great way to keep the exercise ball from rolling around and getting in the way. Try making some extra room in a closet, and just toss the exercise ball in when you’re done with it.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Store an Exercise Ball Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-1.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You’ll probably have to tidy up the closet a bit to make the exercise ball fit. Clear any clutter off the floor so you have plenty of room.</li> \n    <li>If you have an exercise room in your home, try clearing out a whole closet for your other equipment. This way, the whole room will stay nice and neat.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hang a bungee cord in a corner to rest the ball on. There’s a lot of space on your walls for extra storage. Drive 2 screws or nails into the wall at opposite sides of a corner, then attach a bungee cord to the mounts. This creates a little makeshift shelf for your exercise ball to rest on.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Store an Exercise Ball Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-2.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This could also work with a plain string or rope.</li> \n    <li>If you have more than one exercise ball, then you can mount more bungee cords above or below the first one. This gives you more vertical stacking space.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach a large net to your wall for a simple hanging option. A large net can help keep your exercise ball out of the way. Simply find a stud in your wall and drive in a screw or nail. Then hang the net over the nail. This way, you can toss your exercise ball in there when you’re done with it.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Store an Exercise Ball Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-3.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure the net is in a spot where you won’t bump into it. A corner is always a good place.</li> \n    <li>You could also mount the net inside a closet, if you have room, to keep your exercise ball off the floor.</li> \n    <li>Nets are also good for storing other light exercise equipment like mats, straps, and bands.</li> \n    <li>This won’t work for heavier items like medicine balls, so stick with light equipment.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Toss the ball in a large bin to keep it from rolling around. Any kind of storage bin or garbage can will work fine, as long as the exercise ball fits. Just throw the ball in there to prevent it from rolling around the room and getting in your way.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Store an Exercise Ball Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-4.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure the bin is clean so you don’t pick up any germs while you’re working out.</li> \n    <li>This takes up a bit of floorspace, so it might not work if you have a tiny room.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Build a PVC storage rack for multiple exercise balls. This is a bit more involved, but it’s a good way to store multiple exercise balls and other equipment. You can build all kinds of racks with PVC pipe. Just cut the pipes to the correct length to make a rectangular box that fits all of your exercise balls. Make 2 rectangles by screwing the pipes into 3-way elbow joints. Then attach support pipes into the joints at the corners and fit the 2 rectangles together. Now you can enjoy your handy new storage rack.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Store an Exercise Ball Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-5.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For more storage, build multiple levels for the rack. This way, you can stack more equipment or boxes for lots of storage space.</li> \n    <li>You could also build a smaller, square structure to hold a single ball. This keeps the ball in place without taking up a lot of room.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Store-an-Exercise-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Storage Tools\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Storage-Tools\">Storage Tools</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Use a balance base to keep your ball in one place. A balance base is a small platform with a notch that an exercise ball can sit in. This keeps your ball in place so it doesn't roll around. If you want a simple solution for a single ball, then a balance base is a good option.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Store an Exercise Ball Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-6.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Balance bases cost around $30, so they're a cheaper solution than other storage tools.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Get a stability rack to stack your exercise balls. Sporting goods stores have all kinds of pre-made racks to store exercise balls. These range from small mounts that hold single balls to large cases that can hold a lot of equipment. If you really want to keep your gym organized, a rack would be a good choice.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Store an Exercise Ball Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-7.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You’ll probably have to assemble these racks, so follow all the instructions to do it correctly.</li> \n    <li>For vertical storage, there are racks that can stack a few exercise balls above one another. This is great if you don’t have a lot of floor space.</li> \n    <li>There are also shelves that can hold lots of exercise balls of all different sizes. They can also hold heavier equipment like medicine balls.</li> \n    <li>These racks can cost a few hundred dollars, depending on how big they are, so keep that in mind if you’re on a budget.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mount an exercise ball holder onto your wall if you prefer raised storage. There are several types of wall mounts designed for exercise balls. Most hold a single ball for easy storage. Choose a rack and attach it to your wall with a screw or nail. Then toss your exercise ball into it when you’re finished with it.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Store an Exercise Ball Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-8.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Always follow the installation instructions for any rack you use.</li> \n    <li>You could also get a larger wall rack for multiple exercise balls.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Repurpose a stuffed animal holder to store exercise balls. You’ve probably seen stuffed animal holders in toy stores. These are simple boxes with stretchy bungee cords for walls. While they’re meant to hold toys, they’re also great for storing exercise balls. Throw the ball in there when you’re done for a simple storage solution.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Store an Exercise Ball Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-9.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>These can take up a lot of room, so they might not be right if you have limited floorspace.</li> \n    <li>There are also smaller stuffed animal holders that can mount to your wall. This is a good choice for limited space or a single ball.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Store-an-Exercise-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>You also deflate your exercise ball and store it easily in a drawer or closet. However, you probably don’t want to keep filling and deflating your ball every time you want to use it.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Store-an-Exercise-Ball#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Watch out if you mount your exercise ball on your wall! This will stick out and you might bump into it.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Store-an-Exercise-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Exercise balls can roll around when they aren’t stored, so be careful not to trip on yours.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-1.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"e2a7a11f00cbc0764f338a2cbf52d530","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn56@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-27-912_ef13fc89176dbe70.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":74460,"destBytes":40210,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-1.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn56@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-27-912_ef13fc89176dbe70.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-2.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-3.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn97@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-897_36f816077f74681e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-4.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn34@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-40-511_68de7ea01a617609.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-5.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn8@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-41-601_4accc446d320bca4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-6.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn52@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-42-430_f6b54d38888692fc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-7.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn33@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-684_6bd7073b51c00335.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-8.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-8.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-9.jpg/aid12214842-v4-728px-Store-an-Exercise-Ball-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn35@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-41-601_3c9ec6750f0964f4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761719648},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","title":"How to Dry Brush Paint","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Dry brush painting is a painting technique typically used to give wooden furniture a worn, textured look. Finished pieces that have been dry brush painted often look like they took hours to be completed. In reality, dry brush painting is a relatively simple and straightforward technique that almost anyone can learn how to do. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Brush-Paint&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Brush-Paint&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Sanding and Priming Your Furniture\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sanding-and-Priming-Your-Furniture\">Sanding and Priming Your Furniture</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Wood-Furniture\" title=\"Clean Wood Furniture\">Clean and dust your furniture</a> before painting. You’ll want to make sure there’s no dust or debris on your furniture that might prevent your paint from adhering to it. Use a feather or lamb’s wool duster to remove any dust and debris from the surface of your furniture. You can also dampen a clean, soft cloth with water and use that to clean your piece.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Brush Paint Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you opt to use a wet cloth, make sure you dry the piece of furniture with a separate clean, dry cloth before proceeding to paint it.</li> \n    <li>Be sure to only use a clean duster to remove dust and debris from your furniture. Take your duster outside and shake it well to make sure it’s completely clean before using it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Sandpaper\" title=\"Use Sandpaper\">Sand your piece</a> if it’s unvarnished and hasn’t been painted. The dry brush paint technique works best on surfaces that have been sanded down, although you probably shouldn’t sand your furniture if it’s already been painted. If your furniture is unvarnished, lightly sand the surface of it with 150-grit sandpaper, then use a damp cloth to remove the sanding dust.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Sanding the furniture creates a rough surface that allows the paint to adhere to the furniture more easily.</li> \n    <li>You can also use sandpaper that is finer than 150-grit, although using anything rougher than this may cause some damage to your piece.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Detach any hinges, knobs, or pieces of hardware you don’t want to paint. Use a screwdriver to remove anything attached to your furniture that you wouldn’t want to accidentally get paint on. Put the screws in a small container (e.g., a plastic bag) and place them somewhere you won’t lose them.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep the screws and pieces of hardware that you remove together to make it easier for you to reattach them later on.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cover any areas that you don’t want to paint with painter’s tape. There may be some parts of your furniture that you don’t want to paint for aesthetic reasons or that you don’t want to paint but also can’t easily remove (e.g., glass panes on a door). Use painter’s tape to cover these areas and avoid accidentally painting on them.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can buy painter’s tape at any paint or hardware store.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-Wooden-Furniture\" title=\"Paint Wooden Furniture\">Apply a base coat of paint</a> to your furniture if it hasn’t been painted. The dry brush technique works best on furniture that has already been painted, so give your piece a base coat of paint in a solid color if it’s unvarnished. Be sure to allow the piece to dry overnight after painting it.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can use any hue of flat latex paint for your base coat. However, consider using a darker color that will contrast with the shade of paint you’ll use when you dry brush the piece.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Brush-Paint&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Painting With the Dry Brush Technique\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Painting-With-the-Dry-Brush-Technique\">Painting With the Dry Brush Technique</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Pour of mixed paint onto a paper plate. Mix the paint in the can, then slowly pour onto a separate paper plate for you to use to dip your brush in. You can pour slightly more or slightly less paint onto the plate, although you probably won’t need more than this amount to dry brush your furniture.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Alternatively, you may also be able to use the lid to the paint can itself to hold your paint as your painting.</li> \n    <li>There’s no one kind of paint that is most effective for dry brush painting; any kind of paint will do!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Dip your paint brush into the paint so that just the tips are covered. The success of the dry brush technique partially depends on you using only a small amount of paint. Dip your brush very lightly into the paint you’ve poured out and aim to cover only the tips of the brush in paint.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Brush Paint Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You’ll want to dip your brush into the paint in such a way that you’re just able to see that there is a small amount of paint on the bristles.</li> \n    <li>Make sure the bristles still appear separate after you dip them in the paint and don’t stick together. If the bristles are sticking, there’s too much paint on the brush.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Blot your brush on a cloth or paper towel to remove excess paint. Remember, the success of the dry brush technique also depends on making your brush as dry as possible. Use a cloth, paper towel, or some other throwaway item to remove any excess paint while still retaining some color on the brush.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Examples of other throwaway items you might use include another paper plate or a piece of cardboard.</li> \n    <li>Don’t be afraid to remove too much paint from the brush. When dry brushing, it’s better to have too little paint on the brush rather than too much.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use light pressure to quickly apply the paint with small strokes. Your strokes should be light-handed and should be in a back-and-forth motion. Make sure your strokes are quick, as moving too slowly will result in heavy spots of paint on the piece.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Aim to perform 2 to 4 small strokes with your brush before repeating the process of dipping it in the paint and blotting it on a separate cloth or paper towel.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Continue brushing with small, light strokes until the piece is covered. Work from the top of your piece downward until you’ve painted all the areas you wanted to paint. Aim to keep your brush moving as much as possible while you’re painting to minimize the risk of leaving heavy paint spots.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Brush Paint Step 10 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You’ll probably only need to go over each spot with 1 or 2 strokes to achieve a good dry brush effect. However, if you feel a spot can use slightly more color on it, feel free to perform one more pass over it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove or blend heavy spots with a rag or sponge. Once the piece is completely covered, look over it to see if there are any paint clumps that need to be removed or blended into the rest of the paint. You can use a wet cloth to remove the paint or use a sanding sponge to blend it into the surrounding area.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Brush Paint Step 11 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Allow the furniture to dry overnight. Once you’re satisfied with the amount of paint on your piece of furniture, let it dry overnight before moving it or applying any finish to it. You won’t need to apply a second coat, so once it dries it’s ready to be used as normal!<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Brush-Paint#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Brush Paint Step 12 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Brush-Paint&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Keep a clean, wet washcloth nearby as you’re painting, in case you make a mistake and want to wipe it off.</li> \n  <li>To better preserve your dry brush effect, consider spraying 2 coats of clear, water-based polyurethane on the piece after it’s dried.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Brush-Paint&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Make sure to keep children and pets away from any furniture you paint until it’s had a chance to completely dry.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Brush-Paint&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Duster or cloth</li> \n  <li>Sandpaper</li> \n  <li>Screwdriver</li> \n  <li>Painter’s tape</li> \n  <li>Paint brush</li> \n  <li>Paper plate</li> \n  <li>Paper towels</li> \n  <li>Paint</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Brush-Paint&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" noopener\" class=\"external free\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.bobvila.com/articles/dry-brush-technique/\">https://www.bobvila.com/articles/dry-brush-technique/</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 24 Sep 2021 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"5602a679f09e3a13a01d837a9ea7a8d1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn92@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-20-262_c0320490f08dba74.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":41855,"destBytes":24534,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn92@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-20-262_c0320490f08dba74.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn94@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-42-186_fd304d6675489402.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-10-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn89@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-41-148_fe05c3fb0b4af595.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-11-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn78@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-41-138_9c566578d8cf25f7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid10438994-v4-728px-Dry-Brush-Paint-Step-12-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn22@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-42-982_3ae14888acd87008.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761719648},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","title":"How to What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Meeting your significant other’s parents for the first time can be nerve-racking. You want them to like you, but what should you talk about? Whether you’re frantically searching for conversation topics on the car ride over or you’ve got a week to prepare, we’ve got you covered. To help you take the stress out of your visit, read on for talking points and conversation starters you can use to make a great impression on your partner’s family. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Talk about your partner’s strengths.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Talk-about-your-partner’s-strengths.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Talk-about-your-partner.E2.80.99s-strengths.\">Talk about your partner’s strengths.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Let his parents know they did a good job raising him. Express that you’re proud of your partner’s accomplishments and that he treats you well. By showing his parents that you appreciate their son, they’ll be more likely to think highly of you!<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Should-You-Do-if-Your-Parents-Disapprove-of-Your-Relationship-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Should You Do if Your Parents Disapprove of Your Relationship Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/What-Should-You-Do-if-Your-Parents-Disapprove-of-Your-Relationship-Step-4.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Should-You-Do-if-Your-Parents-Disapprove-of-Your-Relationship-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Share a moment when your partner did something you admired: “I feel really lucky to be dating Sam. He’s so considerate, and yesterday, he helped a kid fix her bike chain.”</li> \n    <li>Talk about your partner’s success: “I’m so proud that Zamari got promoted. He works so hard!”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Start a conversation about your partner’s childhood.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Start-a-conversation-about-your-partner’s-childhood.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Start-a-conversation-about-your-partner.E2.80.99s-childhood.\">Start a conversation about your partner’s childhood.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Ask what your partner was like when he was younger. This one’s a super easy and fun topic, especially if you aren’t sure what to say. Parents usually love to talk about their kids, and they might even offer up some funny anecdotes.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-1.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>“I bet William was the class clown in middle school. What did his teachers think of him?”</li> \n    <li>“What was Kuhan like when he was younger?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Inquire about family photos.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Inquire-about-family-photos.\">Inquire about family photos.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Get the story behind a framed photo or even a screensaver. You can learn more about your significant other’s family history or childhood by starting a conversation around a photo. Just be sure to keep your comments respectful, and understand that a photo might capture a really meaningful memory of a loved one or place.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-2.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Point out resemblances: “Is that Ishaan’s grandfather? They have the same eyes.”</li> \n    <li>Ask about photo locations: “Where did you take this photo? It’s so beautiful.”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Ask about family vacations or activities.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ask-about-family-vacations-or-activities.\">Ask about family vacations or activities.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Keep the conversation fun by inquiring about past, present, or future travel plans. If your partner’s family hasn’t gone anywhere specific, you can ask about where they’d like to vacation. You can even ask about family traditions or local trips if his parents don’t travel.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-3.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Get the scoop on family traditions: “Jacob told me you do family picnics every Sunday. Where do you go?”</li> \n    <li>Learn about past trips: “How was your backpacking trip?”</li> \n    <li>Find out about future plans: “What would your dream vacation look like?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Get them talking about where they grew up.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Get-them-talking-about-where-they-grew-up.\">Get them talking about where they grew up.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Start with a simple question to learn about their city or region. Then, you can ask more specific questions about their favorite things to do in the area, how they ended up somewhere else (if they moved), or how they decided to stay (if they’re in the same place now). People like to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Get-Someone-to-Talk-About-Themselves\" title=\"Get Someone to Talk About Themselves\">talk about themselves</a>, and you’ll get to learn more about the family who raised the person you’re dating. If you can do a little research ahead of time, you can even look up the place and then ask them about a specific feature of their hometown.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-4.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re not familiar with the area, ask, “What did you like most about growing up there?”</li> \n    <li>If you know something about the area, follow up with a specific question like, “Wow. They have that great stadium there, right? Did you ever go to a game?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Ask for book, movie, or music recommendations.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Ask-for-book,-movie,-or-music-recommendations.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ask-for-book.2C-movie.2C-or-music-recommendations.\">Ask for book, movie, or music recommendations.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Learn about their tastes and see if you have things in common. Talking about popular media is a great entry-level conversation topic if you don’t know much about his family. Once his parents let you know about their interests, ask follow-up questions to show that you value their perspective and to keep the conversation going. You can even share a book, movie, or band you like that seems similar to what they’re mentioning.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-5.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>“Have you read anything good lately?”</li> \n    <li>“What’s the best movie you’ve seen?”</li> \n    <li>“What music do you like listening to?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Bond over shared interests.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Bond-over-shared-interests.\">Bond over shared interests.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Ask your partner beforehand about his parents’ interests. Interests can mean hobbies, skills, background, etc. If you have anything in common, prepare a few thoughtful questions to ask about that bit of common ground. Keep in mind, you’ll want to stay authentic, so don’t pretend to like something for the sake of making conversation. They want to get to know the real you.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-6.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>“Marcel mentioned that you’re interested in gardening. I’m starting an herb garden. Do you have any tips?”</li> \n    <li>“I want to study to become a doctor. What do you like about your career?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Bring up your partner’s other family members.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Bring-up-your-partner’s-other-family-members.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Bring-up-your-partner.E2.80.99s-other-family-members.\">Bring up your partner’s other family members.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Show his parents you’re interested in learning about his family. Whether or not you’ve met your partner’s siblings, you can ask about how they’re doing or what they’re like. If there’s a beloved family pet, you can ask about where they got the pet, how they named the pet, and ask to see cute pictures of the animal.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-7.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>“Your daughter is studying to be a nurse, right? How does she like her school?”</li> \n    <li>“I’ve never gotten to meet his older brother. What’s he like?”</li> \n    <li>“Harvey seems like a great dog. Do you have any puppy pictures of him?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Give compliments and express thanks.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Give-compliments-and-express-thanks.\">Give compliments and express thanks.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>If you’re ever unsure what to say, try this. Pick out a nice aspect of the family home/venue, a unique decoration, or delicious part of the meal and genuinely express your admiration and gratitude. You’ll win your partner’s family over by being polite, and you can use the object as a jumping off point for conversation. Follow up your compliment with an <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Ask-Open-Ended-Questions\" title=\"Ask Open Ended Questions\">open-ended question</a> about the thing you’re admiring.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-8.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Compliment décor: “This living room feels so bright and welcoming. Where did you get that sofa?”</li> \n    <li>Mention the meal: “Thank you so much for dinner. Where did you learn how to make this?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Stay away from controversial topics.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stay-away-from-controversial-topics.\">Stay away from controversial topics.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Steer clear of family drama, religion, and politics. If someone else brings up a controversial topic and you disagree with what they’re saying, consider whether it’s worth weighing in. If you feel super strongly about the cause or issue, you can voice your opinion in a respectful and well-informed way. Alternatively, if you’re not comfortable expressing disagreement, wait to share your opinion until you know his family better.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-9.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Express polite disagreement by saying, “I have a slightly different perspective on that,” which is more subtle than “I disagree.”<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Laugh off awkward comments or say, “I really don’t know what to say!”<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Avoid complaining or criticizing.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Avoid-complaining-or-criticizing.\">Avoid complaining or criticizing.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Whether you’re asked about movies or your work, stay positive. If someone asks you about something you don’t like, try to redirect the conversation. It’s okay to express a little bit of dislike or to state when you disagree, but do it tastefully and with moderation so that you don’t seem rude.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"What Are Some Topics to Talk About when Meeting His Parents Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-10.jpg/aid12609679-v4-728px-What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can redirect the conversation by asking a question about someone else’s life, “That class wasn’t my favorite, but I learned a lot. What’s something that stuck with you from college?”</li> \n    <li>If you feel strongly, try to temper your criticism, “Oh, that movie wasn’t my favorite, but I thought the music was really beautiful.”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.glamour.com/story/4-parents-approved-dinner-conv\">https://www.glamour.com/story/4-parents-approved-dinner-conv</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\">[v161582_b01]. 1 October class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.cosmopolitan.com/sex-love/advice/g2234/meeting-the-parents/?slide=3\">https://www.cosmopolitan.com/sex-love/advice/g2234/meeting-the-parents/?slide=3</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\"   <li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a <li id=\"_note-15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/What-Are-Some-Topics-to-Talk-About-when-Meeting-His-Parents#_ref-15\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\"
