</li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 26 Sep 2021 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"62fba9e86617b027d1cc854b4ed2fffb","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn76@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-24-205_57f996e8f450f32f.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":62729,"destBytes":38402,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn76@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-24-205_57f996e8f450f32f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn12@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-41-974_bc3282c83ecd7728.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-3.jpg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn93@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-42-645_c317cc5e3eff1aa2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn83@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-39-405_d88770b2b35c049e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn41@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-42-724_a1302774fb671d67.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn92@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-41-934_baa4609be4374499.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Recycle-Newspaper-Step-3.jpg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Recycle-Newspaper-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn20@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-40-444_be7842cc158935a6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Build-a-Campfire-Pit-Step-9.jpeg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Build-a-Campfire-Pit-Step-9.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn58@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-42-182_03b98fe220e89f9b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-9.jpg/aid12500200-v4-728px-Plant-Trees-to-Fight-Climate-Change-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn86@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-42-521_cb96a19da2f6f351.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761719655},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","title":"How to Play Four Square","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Four Square is a fun playground game that almost anyone can play. All you need is chalk or tape to make the squares, a ball that will bounce, and at least 4 players. Try playing with the standard rules, or mix it up for some fun! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Play-Four-Square&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Play-Four-Square&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Playing Basic Four Square\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Playing-Basic-Four-Square\">Playing Basic Four Square</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Mark 4 squares on the ground. You can make the squares any size you want, but make sure you have enough room to play. Make the squares about per side for most players, although adults might enjoy the challenge from squares.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Play-Four-Square-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Number the squares from 1 to 4. The squares should be numbered clockwise starting with 1. This means the 1 and 3 squares will be diagonal from each other, as will the 2 and 4 squares.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Play-Four-Square-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Some people use the letters A, B, C, and D instead of numbers, while others use titles of royalty, such as Jack, Queen, King, and Ace.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a standard rubber playground ball if you have one. This is often called a kickball and is a rubber ball about in diameter. If you don’t have a playground ball, use any ball that’s and bounces at least 50% of the height from which it was thrown.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Play-Four-Square-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Australian players use felted tennis balls to play Four Square.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make sure everyone agrees on the rules before you start playing. As a \"playground game\" this game has spawned an incredible amount of local variations over the decades.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Play-Four-Square-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re playing by the standard rules, make sure everyone knows what exactly they are before starting. While often one school might have \"standard rules\" the new kid might think the \"standard rules\" are something else entirely.</li> \n    <li>If you’re playing by variations, or if the server is allowed to make up rules during the game, make sure everyone is aware of this and agrees to it.</li> \n    <li>Having everyone on the same page before the game starts will help prevent disputes during the game that could ruin the fun.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Have a player stand in each square. The players don’t have to stay in their square the entire time, but they should stay close in order to defend their area.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Play-Four-Square-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Serve the ball from the highest-ranked square to the lowest. The server should bounce the ball once in their own square, then hit the ball so that it goes diagonally to the lowest-ranked square. The receiver can then hit the ball in any direction they choose.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Play-Four-Square-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Many people play Four Square so that the 4 square is the highest-ranked square, and therefore the server’s square. If this is the case, the server should stand in the 4 square and hit the ball towards the 1 square.</li> \n    <li>Some people play the game so 1 is the highest-ranked square and 4 is the lowest. In this case, the serve would go from the 1 square towards the 4 square.</li> \n    <li>The serve always goes in the same direction.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Allow one fault for the receiver per round. After the serve, the receiver should allow the ball to bounce one time in their square, then should hit it in whatever direction they choose. If they don’t hit the ball correctly or it goes out of bounds, that is a “fault,” and one fault is allowed per round. If the receiver misses the serve twice in a round, they are eliminated.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Play-Four-Square-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The round lasts until a player is eliminated.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take turns hitting the ball after it bounces in your square. Once the ball is in play, whoever’s square the ball lands in should be the next to hit it. The ball is considered “in play” after someone touches it but before it lands in another square, meaning players can hit the ball in the air. You must hit the ball before it bounces a second time.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Play-Four-Square-Step-8.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If a player hits the line with the ball or hits the ball so it does not land in another player’s square, that player is out.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If a player hits a ball after it has landed in another player’s square, the person who hit the ball is out. This is called “poaching.”<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hit the ball with any part of your hand but do not catch it. Players are not allowed to carry, catch, or hold the ball during play. However, they may repeatedly bounce the ball off of their hands in order to avoid breaking this rule.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Play-Four-Square-Step-9.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Advance to a higher numbered square when a player is out. The goal of the game is to move up to the servers’ square. If you have more than 4 players, a new player will move into the lowest-numbered square when a player is eliminated.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Play-Four-Square-Step-10.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you only have 4 players, the person who is out moves to the lowest-numbered square and the other players move up, if applicable.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Play-Four-Square&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Playing Variations on the Game\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Playing-Variations-on-the-Game\">Playing Variations on the Game</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Allow young players to catch the ball for an easier version of Four Square. Younger or less-skilled players might have more fun if they can catch the ball before throwing it again.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Play-Four-Square-Step-11.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Assign 2 players per square if you have 8 or more players. Play a relay-style variation of Four Square by having 2 players for each square. Whenever one player hits the ball to another square, they’ll jump out of their court and their partner will jump in.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Play-Four-Square-Step-12.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When playing with 2 players per square, if one player is out then the team is out. If everyone agrees, however, you can adjust the rules to allow the other team member to continue playing until they are out.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hit the ball into your own square first for an Australian variation. Australian players must bounce the ball in their own square, regardless of whether the ball has already bounced in their own square. Also, in Australian Four Square the ball is allowed to touch the line.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Play-Four-Square-Step-13.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Play Black Jack to get players out faster. In Black Jack, if a player can catch the ball before it lands in their square, then the person who hit the ball is out. This usually makes the game move faster.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Play-Four-Square-Step-14.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Allow the server to make up special rules to keep the game changing. The server can call a rule that all of the players must follow, but it only lasts for that round. When the round is over, the server must call the rules again or else it’s assumed there are no special rules.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Play-Four-Square-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Play Four Square Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Play-Four-Square-Step-15.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A special rule might be something like 7-Up, in which each player who hits the ball has to call out a number one higher than the previous player. The player who hits on the number 7, or any number that ends in 7, must skip that number or they’ll be out.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Another rule the server might call could be Underhand, in which all of the hits must be made with the back of the hand. Players should keep their hands open and their palms facing up.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Four-Square#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Play-Four-Square&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Play-Four-Square&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fold-a-Paper-Rose\" title=\"Fold a Paper Rose\">Fold a Paper Rose</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Win-at-Tic-Tac-Toe\" title=\"Win at Tic Tac Toe\">Win at Tic Tac Toe</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Boxball\" title=\"Play Boxball\">Play Boxball</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Play-Four-Square&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Play-Four-Square-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"8413ca299f44b87e61153b9aef0e7874","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn31@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-26-370_2913289ebbc66cc1.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":14268,"destBytes":4968,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Play-Four-Square-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn31@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-26-370_2913289ebbc66cc1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Play-Four-Square-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn46@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-42-026_d2c45d9078ea19fe.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Play-Four-Square-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn61@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-42-061_07509d4d7e9b5f6a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Play-Four-Square-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn21@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-40-969_0d5dcb8b75177a76.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Play-Four-Square-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn32@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-350_6d7f60b4f907a8cd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Play-Four-Square-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn27@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-40-083_94d5230aff1000ed.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Play-Four-Square-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn92@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-40-393_f0fd56d4eaa4b53d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Play-Four-Square-Step-8.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn94@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-41-320_af85a24b6a845479.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Play-Four-Square-Step-9.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn85@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-47-316_3831f9023cab0644.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Play-Four-Square-Step-10.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn51@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-43-161_eaa1b241967f69c2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Play-Four-Square-Step-11.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn4@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-42-305_d01e57b12fa0f048.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Play-Four-Square-Step-12.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn12@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-40-248_d52ca8b333dd91ed.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Play-Four-Square-Step-13.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn43@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-40-118_a5b9e29e2fe2bc19.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Play-Four-Square-Step-14.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn18@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-41-630_15b1b1628df9273e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Play-Four-Square-Step-15.jpg/aid36378-v4-728px-Play-Four-Square-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn90@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-42-537_0584d0a91e343e42.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761719622},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","title":"How to How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>The plank exercise is a great way to strengthen your core, your back, and your legs. As a beginner, you might not be able to hold a plank for very long, which is okay! We’ve answered your questions about the plank so you can set your own goals and work your way toward a stronger body. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: How long should I hold the plank for best results?\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"How-long-should-I-hold-the-plank-for-best-results?\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"How-long-should-I-hold-the-plank-for-best-results.3F\">How long should I hold the plank for best results?</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Aim for 10 to 30 seconds at a time. When you first start out, you might only be able to hold a plank for 5 to 10 seconds, and that’s okay! As you get stronger and your body gets used to the position, try holding it for longer and longer.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-1.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Hold a plank for 2 minutes maximum. Experts note that after 2 minutes, you’ve reached the maximum benefits that the plank can give you. If you can hold it for 2 minutes straight without wavering, you’re building muscles and burning calories to reach your fitness goals.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-2.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: How do you do a plank correctly?\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"How-do-you-do-a-plank-correctly?\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"How-do-you-do-a-plank-correctly.3F\">How do you do a plank correctly?</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Balance on your forearms and your toes with your body off the ground. Start by lying on your stomach with your forearms underneath you. Keep your elbows directly underneath your shoulders with your palms down. Engage your abs and your torso to rise up onto your toes, keeping your hips and stomach off the ground. Squeeze your legs and your glutes to keep your body in a straight line.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-3.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Holding the plank only works if you’re in the right formation. If you have to sway your back or raise your rear end to hold the plank, it’s time to drop down and take a rest.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: How many reps of planks should I do?\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"How-many-reps-of-planks-should-I-do?\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"How-many-reps-of-planks-should-I-do.3F\">How many reps of planks should I do?</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Try doing 1 to 6 reps every day. When you first start out, you may only be able to hold one plank a day, which is fine! As you build strength, you can work your way up to 2 planks, then 3, and so on.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-4.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you can’t do all 6 planks in a row, that’s totally fine. It might be easier to space them out throughout the day.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Is holding a plank for 30 seconds good?\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Is-holding-a-plank-for-30-seconds-good?\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Is-holding-a-plank-for-30-seconds-good.3F\">Is holding a plank for 30 seconds good?</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Yes, especially for a beginner! Half a minute is a great amount of time to hold a plank, especially if you’ve never done it before. If you can’t reach 30 seconds right away, don’t sweat it—just keep trying until you can.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-5.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: What happens if you do planks every day?\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"What-happens-if-you-do-planks-every-day?\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"What-happens-if-you-do-planks-every-day.3F\">What happens if you do planks every day?</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>You’ll strengthen your core. Planks are a great full body workout that target your abs and your core muscles. If you do planks every day, you’ll probably notice that your core muscles are stronger, which is great for balancing and holding your form during other exercises.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-6.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>You’ll also strengthen your legs. In the plank, your glutes, quads, and hamstrings are also getting a workout. Squeeze your legs tightly in the plank position to get the full effect of this exercise.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-7.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Does the plank get easier?\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Does-the-plank-get-easier?\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Does-the-plank-get-easier.3F\">Does the plank get easier?</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Yes, the plank gets easier the more often you do it. When you first start out, you might feel shaky or weak as you hold the position. Keep squeezing your legs and your abs, and try to hold a plank for longer periods every time you do it.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-8.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re struggling to hold the plank position, keep your arms in place but drop down to your knees. You’ll still work your abs and your core, but your legs won’t have to work quite as hard.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Are planks cardio or strength exercises?\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Are-planks-cardio-or-strength-exercises?\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Are-planks-cardio-or-strength-exercises.3F\">Are planks cardio or strength exercises?</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Planks are mostly a strength-building exercise. Since you’re holding a static position and flexing your muscles the entire time, you’re working on building muscular strength. If you’d like to add some cardio to your plank exercises, try modifying them with hip touches or up and down planks.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"How Long to Hold a Plank As a Beginner Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-9.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Hip touches: Start in a standard plank with your body in a straight line. Slowly rotate your right hip down to the floor, raising your left hip in the air. Keep your body in a straight line as you gently touch your right hip on the ground. Then, rotate your left hip to the left side.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Up and downs: Start in a standard plank position with your forearms on the floor. Press up with your right hand so you’re balancing with your right palm flat on the floor. Then, press up with your left hand so you have both palms flat on the floor. Quickly lower back down to your right forearm, then your left forearm. Keep your abs engaged and your body in a straight line the entire time.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you feel any pain in your lower back during a plank, squeeze your glutes to get your body back into a straight line.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/straight-talk-on-planking-2019111318304\">https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/straight-talk-on-planking-2019111318304</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/straight-talk-on-planking-2019111318304\">https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/straight-talk-on-planking-2019111318304</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_ref-3\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" id=\"_note-4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_ref-4\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer   <li id=\"_note-5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_ref-5\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\"   <li id=\"_note-6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/straight-talk-on-planking-2019111318304\">https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/straight-talk-on-planking-2019111318304</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer href=\"https://www.ahealthiermichigan.org/2013/07/31/the-exercise-benefits-of-the-plank-position/\">https://www.ahealthiermichigan.org/2013/07/31/the-exercise-benefits-of-the-plank-position/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 23 Sep 2021 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-1.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"f5aef5c6f2e11624912a400f58a685cb","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn60@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-35-254_687b34e45beda565.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":62915,"destBytes":37788,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-1.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn60@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-35-254_687b34e45beda565.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-2.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn48@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-42-427_0cb6e5b170c4e000.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-3.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn30@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-41-371_80a2e76f1f935d10.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-4.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn36@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-42-302_849c612ddb956a33.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-5.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn72@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-821_a36b6c0e87c8ba36.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-6.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn52@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-40-102_41d2e048936d9cba.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-7.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn5@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-43-031_b19f03a98a9bf8e8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-8.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn70@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-42-082_6e1e1bc2b50ad3b2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-9.jpg/aid12705946-v4-728px-How-Long-to-Hold-a-Plank-As-a-Beginner-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn22@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-41-278_aedf20ffa817ac9f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761719660},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:19","title":"How to Clean Old Rubber","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Rubber is durable and can handle the elements pretty well, but it’s still bound to get dirty from time to time. While you can usually get away with a light surface cleaning for most pieces of rubber, you may need to resort to some stronger cleaners if there are stains or stuck-on residue. Even though a lot of things are made from rubber, you can use many of the same cleaning methods no matter what’s dirty. We’ll walk you through some of the most common ways to clean and give you some helpful tips to make your rubber look like new! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Old-Rubber&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Old-Rubber&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Dry Cleaning\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Dry-Cleaning\">Dry Cleaning</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Run a duster over the surface to pick up surface dirt. Use a feather duster or a soft lint-free cloth without any spray or cleaning chemicals. Gently wipe the rubber’s surface with your duster to pick up any loose particles that are stuck to it. Pay close attention to any cracks or crevices where dirt may gather.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-1.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Dusters work well on any small piece of rubber, such as on keyboards or appliances.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Spray compressed air to clear dust in hard-to-reach spots. Pick up a can of compressed air from your local convenience or office supply store. Hold the can upright and aim the nozzle at the piece you’re cleaning. Press the button down in short bursts until you don’t see any more dust left on the surface.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-2.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Compressed air works best for cleaning rubber gaskets, seals, and keyboards.</li> \n    <li>Avoid holding the can of compressed air upside-down since it could cause liquid to spill out.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Vacuum the rubber to remove the most dirt and dust. Turn your vacuum to the medium setting and use a rolling beater-brush attachment if you have one. Run the vacuum over the surface a few times to pick up all of the dirt that’s still stuck on the rubber.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7c/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-3.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Sweeping doesn’t work very well on rubber floors since the dirt and residue might stick to it.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Avoid using a canister vacuum where the head drags on the floor since it could leave marks and cause wear and tear.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stick to dry cleaning methods for any antique or vintage rubber. If the rubber is old or damaged, water could make it worse if you clean with it. If you’re not sure about the age of the rubber or if it’s safe to get wet, only use a duster, soft brush, or vacuum when you’re cleaning.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-4.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Old-Rubber&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Light Cleaning with Soap and Water\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Light-Cleaning-with-Soap-and-Water\">Light Cleaning with Soap and Water</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Try using only water at first. If you’re working with old rubber, like on classic bike or car tires, cleaners could be too abrasive. Rinse the piece of rubber with warm water and work it gently onto the surface by hand rather than using a brush since you could damage the rubber and cause it to deteriorate.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-5.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Mix liquid dish soap or laundry detergent with warm water. You’ll need enough water to either wipe the entire surface or submerge the piece completely. Fill a container with water and add a squirt of any type of liquid dish soap or dish detergent. Stir the soap into the water thoroughly until it starts to form a thin layer of suds.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-6.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Soak the rubber for about 15 minutes in the water if possible. Set the rubber in the soapy water so it’s completely submerged. Let the soap loosen any stains or residue that are still on the surface so they’re easier to scrub off later on.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-7.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This works especially well for cleaning rubber soles on shoes and rubber bath toys.</li> \n    <li>If you can’t submerge the piece of rubber, gently wipe the soapy water onto the surface with a lint-free cloth.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Brush the rubber with a microfiber cloth or soft-bristle brush. Gently work the soapy solution into the rubber using a dedicated cleaning brush or an old toothbrush. Focus on any areas that still have stains or residue caked on the rubber’s surface. Work the bristles into any nooks and crannies to ensure you get all of the dirt.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-8.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This works well for rubber car mats, camper tops, or shoe soles.</li> \n    <li>If you’re cleaning a rubber floor, use a soft sponge mop to scrub the surface.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Scrub baking soda into the rubber to lift stains and remove odors. While the piece of rubber is still wet, sprinkle a thin layer of baking soda onto the surface and leave it to dry for 5 minutes. Then, use your cleaning brush or an old toothbrush to scrub the baking soda off of the rubber. If there were any stains or odors, they should be less noticeable!<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-9.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Baking soda works really well for rubber sandals.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Let the rubber dry completely. If water was able to get inside the piece of rubber, squeeze out as much as you can. Set the piece in a cool, dry area that gets a lot of air flow so the water evaporates and doesn’t cause any mold or mildew to form.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup> If you need to speed up the drying process, try placing the rubber in front of a fan or AC vent.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-10.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you were cleaning rubber floor mats, let them dry out completely before putting them back in your vehicle.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Old-Rubber&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Deep Cleaning\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Deep-Cleaning\">Deep Cleaning</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Spray the rubber with a hose or pressure washer to break apart gunk. Turn your hose onto a medium or strong setting and spray your piece of rubber with water. Try to remove as much of the loose dirt and dust particles as you can.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-11.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t have a hose at home, go to a self-service car wash and see if they have a pressure washer available to use.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Scrub an ammonia solution on the rubber to lift up dirt and grime. In a large bucket, add of warm water, of liquid dish soap, and of ammonia and mix it together. Use a mop or a scrub brush to apply your cleaner to the rubber and leave it to sit for 10 minutes. After that, scrub the rubber with a soft-bristle brush to lift up any stains or grime. Finish off by rinsing the rubber with clean water.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-12.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Test the cleaning solution on a small portion of the rubber before using it. If the area appears chalky after a few minutes, the cleaner may be breaking the rubber down. Add more water to dilute it before trying again.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Apply a hydrogen peroxide solution to brighten stains. Combine of warm water, of liquid dish soap, and of hydrogen peroxide. Spread the solution over the rubber’s surface with a mop or cloth and leave it to soak for 10 minutes. Work the cleaner into the surface with a soft-bristled brush before rinsing away the stains and residue.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b2/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-13.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want to lighten the rubber even more or if it wasn’t effective, try applying the cleaner a second time.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a commercial degreaser for stubborn residue. Get a commercial rubber degreaser from an automotive supply store and spray it generously on the pieces of rubber you’re cleaning. Let the degreaser sit on the rubber for a few minutes before scrubbing it gently with a stiff-bristled brush. Rinse the rubber off with clean water from a hose or pressure washer to remove any leftover residue.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-14.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This method works well for rubber vehicle mats.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove sticky residue by applying acetone. Dip the corner of a lint-free cloth in a little bit of acetone and gently work it into the surface. Coat the entire area that feels sticky to the touch and carefully wipe the residue away with the cloth. The acetone will evaporate right off of the rubber so it will dry on its own pretty fast.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-15.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Acetone is very flammable and may cause eye irritation, so be cautious when you use it.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Use acetone on things like rubber phone cases or shoe soles.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Buff with a rubber conditioner to make it shine. Look for a high-quality rubber conditioner or lubricant at your local big box store. You can buff by hand or use a buffing machine if the piece of rubber is large enough. Apply the conditioner to the buffing pad and work it into the piece of rubber to keep it shiny and in good condition.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Old Rubber Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-16.jpg/aid12701641-v4-728px-Clean-Old-Rubber-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you use a buffing machine, make sure it runs at less than 350 RPM, or else it could damage rubber floors.</li> \n    <li>If you don’t have a rubber conditioner, mix of fabric softener with of water.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Old-Rubber&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Give your rubber a quick dust or vacuum every day so they don’t develop a lot of build-up.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Try deep cleaning with soap and water at least every 3 days.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Rubber gets pretty slippery when it’s wet, so break the area down into 4 or 5 smaller sections and work on one area at a time.<sup id=\"_ref-24\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 24\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-24\">[24]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Wipe down the entire piece of rubber down with silicone lubricant so it’s less likely to dry out and crack.<sup id=\"_ref-25\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 25\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-25\">[25]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Try cleaning rubber stamps with alcohol-free baby wipes so you don’t use harsh abrasives on the delicate pieces.<sup id=\"_ref-26\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 26\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-26\">[26]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Rubber can get hard and brittle over time, but glycerin can help rejuvenate it. Place the stamp so the rubber is face-up and wipe on a thin layer of glycerin on the surface. Leave the glycerin to sit overnight and then wipe it off with a damp towel the next day.<sup id=\"_ref-27\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 27\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-27\">[27]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Old-Rubber&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Avoid using paint thinner, WD-40, or any other solvent based cleaners since they’re more likely to damage the rubber.<sup id=\"_ref-28\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 28\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-28\">[28]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Bleach, acidic detergents, and turpentine could leave stains on rubber, so avoid cleaning with them.<sup id=\"_ref-29\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 29\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Old-Rubber#_note-29\">[29]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Old-Rubber&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/m4d-iIbkJy8?t=105\">https://youtu.be/m4d-iIbkJy8?t=105</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-26\"><a target=\"_blank\"
